reviews.body:
Use the updated version to parse a junit xml file without "start" and "end" property failed with `KeyError`.
```
(env-python3) ubuntu@94879e0f3ae9:~/code/sonic-mgmt/test_reporting$ cat ../tests/test_cat.xml 
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<testsuite errors="0" failures="1" name="pytest" skipped="3" tests="6" time="18.733">
    <properties>
        <property name="topology" value="t0" />
        <property name="testbed" value="vms-kvm-t0" />
        <property name="timestamp" value="2021-11-18 01:08:35.603651" />
        <property name="host" value="vlab-01" />
        <property name="asic" value="vs" />
        <property name="platform" value="x86_64-kvm_x86_64-r0" />
        <property name="hwsku" value="Force10-S6000" />
        <property name="os_version" value="master.36262-db529af20" />
    </properties>
    <testcase classname="test_cat" file="test_cat.py" line="12" name="test_case1_xfail_strict" time="14.117">
        <skipped message="Test" type="pytest.xfail"></skipped>
    </testcase>
    <testcase classname="test_cat" file="test_cat.py" line="32" name="test_case2_xfail" time="0.006">
        <skipped message="Test" type="pytest.xfail"></skipped>
    </testcase>
    <testcase classname="test_cat" file="test_cat.py" line="36" name="test_case3_pass_xfail_strict" time="0.455">
        <failure message="[XPASS(strict)] Test">[XPASS(strict)] Test</failure>
    </testcase>
    <testcase classname="test_cat" file="test_cat.py" line="39" name="test_case4_pass_xfail" time="0.530"></testcase>
    <testcase classname="test_cat" file="test_cat.py" line="42" name="test_case5_pass" time="0.582"></testcase>
    <testcase classname="test_cat" file="test_cat.py" line="45" name="test_case6_skip" time="0.013">
        <skipped message="Test" type="pytest.skip">test_cat.py:45: Test</skipped>
    </testcase>
</testsuite>
(env-python3) ubuntu@94879e0f3ae9:~/code/sonic-mgmt/test_reporting$ python junit_xml_parser.py ../tests/test_cat.xml             
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "junit_xml_parser.py", line 686, in <module>
    _run_script()      
  File "junit_xml_parser.py", line 671, in _run_script
    test_result_json = parse_test_result(roots)
  File "junit_xml_parser.py", line 348, in parse_test_result
    test_cases = _parse_test_cases(root)
  File "junit_xml_parser.py", line 470, in _parse_test_cases
    feature, result = _parse_test_case(test_case)                                                                                                                                                                                                               
  File "junit_xml_parser.py", line 426, in _parse_test_case
    if testcase_properties[attribute]:
KeyError: 'start'     
```

This change is supposed to support junti xml result file with or without the "start" and "end" testcase properties.

Should we consider doing a warmboot as well?

> Should we consider doing a warmboot as well?

The reason not to do warmboot is to save time. There are multiple combinations of decap config for ttl/dscp. To verify each configuration with warmboot included will lead to test_decap running for an hour. CPA setup and teardown is able to replicate the same scenario here and saves time.

To validate decap and other scenarios after warmboot, the test sequence in nightly needs to be adjusted. This is a different work stream though which requires adapting existing testcases accordingly too.

comments.body: /azp run
Azure Pipelines successfully started running 1 pipeline(s).

> @yejianquan could you elaborate more why we want to loose the condition for the packet loss rate? Is that because the performance of PTF, or portchannel add/removal will cause pkt loss?

Hi @StormLiangMS ,  I've figured out that the packet loss happened not because of the performance of PTF, but the member change of port channel.
So the problem becomes: Is it reasonable for the packet loss during member updating?
Portchannel provides reliability: The Ethernet links back up one another. When a physical Ethernet link fails, the traffic originally intended for the failed link is switched to the remaining active links. But nowhere says that it won't loss any packet during the switching.
From my point of view:
1. Only quite few packets will be lost, in my local  run, it always loss only 1 packet(20,000~40,000 packets in total). In production scenario, if packets lost, the sender shall resend it with TCP, 1% is an acceptable number to me
2. Generally, we would not modify members without isolating.

So I think the slightly packet loss is acceptable.

> > @yejianquan could you elaborate more why we want to loose the condition for the packet loss rate? Is that because the performance of PTF, or portchannel add/removal will cause pkt loss?
> 
> Hi @StormLiangMS , I've figured out that the packet loss happened not because of the performance of PTF, but the member change of port channel. So the problem becomes: Is it reasonable for the packet loss during member updating? Portchannel provides reliability: The Ethernet links back up one another. When a physical Ethernet link fails, the traffic originally intended for the failed link is switched to the remaining active links. But nowhere says that it won't loss any packet during the switching. From my point of view:
> 
> 1. Only quite few packets will be lost, in my local  run, it always loss only 1 packet(20,000~40,000 packets in total). In production scenario, if packets lost, the sender shall resend it with TCP, 1% is an acceptable number to me
> 2. Generally, we would not modify members without isolating.
> 
> So I think the slightly packet loss is acceptable.

@yejianquan I think this one we may need to discuss with the feature owner, in my view, this should be a feature requirement, no pkt drop when add/remove ports from port channel group. 
For the adding, there should be no pkt drop, when we do the add, it will be effective after we adding this port, then the traffic would be scheduled to the new members. 
For the deletion, the in-flight pkt maybe dropped in the receiving side of neighbor device, but for sure, there should be someway we can avoid that kind of drop. 
My point is that the test behavior should be align with feature design.

reviews.body: @yejianquan could you elaborate more why we want to loose the condition for the packet loss rate? Is that because the performance of PTF, or portchannel add/removal will cause pkt loss?

@yxieca FYI

> 
Hi @ZhaohuiS 
For IPv4, the optimized time should be the difference between time stamps of the following message, ~15s
```
2022-06-06 07:26:50 test_route_perf.exec_routes              L0203 INFO   | All route entries have been installed in ASIC_DB in 66.122285 seconds
2022-06-06 07:27:04 test_route_perf.test_perf_add_remove_rou L0253 INFO   | Time to set 100000 ipv4 routes is 66.12 seconds.
```
There is no too much log message in the original script but the time before optimizing can be estimated as `end-2-end-time` - `time used to push to ASIC_DB`, which is `21 minutes 36 seconds` - `~70 seconds` => `20 minutes 26 seconds`
```
2022-06-06 03:50:10 test_route_perf.test_perf_add_remove_rou L0229 INFO   | IP route utilization before test start: Used: 6414, Available: 186352, Test count: 100000
2022-06-06 04:08:05 test_route_perf.test_perf_add_remove_rou L0244 INFO   | Time to set 100000 ipv4 routes is 69.45 seconds.
2022-06-06 04:12:46 test_route_perf.test_perf_add_remove_rou L0248 INFO   | Time to del 100000 ipv4 routes is 50.76 seconds.
```
IPv6 is the same.

@rawal01 Please help review since you are the original creator of this testcase.
Is there a test case to check if a module in skip list is NOT online?

> Is there a test case to check if a module in skip list is NOT online?

Current test case does not check any skipped modules.  It assumes if it is skipped, it is not there and it does not try to validate what the output should be for those skipped modules perhaps it thinks it is irrelevant...  I think in future this testcase can be further enhanced to capture other verifications.  One thing that came to mind is in the future we should add test to see if we admin shut the LC, what are the expected show output for the admin shut LC(s) and once admin no shut, we should also expect it to be online...  this will also require the chassis vendors to support admin shut/no shut on the LCs.

Hi, it seems that these changes may affect our current work with NAT tests. We currently have the ability to run a test with a parameter that includes this feature on the device during setup. 
`--enable_nat_feature`
And if the NAT feature was not enabled (by this parameter or by default), the test is skipped.
With this implementation, the test does not have time to turn on the NAT feature during startup, and the test is skipped, which does not allow working with sonic builds in which the NAT feature is not enabled by default.

> Hi, it seems that these changes may affect our current work with NAT tests. We currently have the ability to run a test with a parameter that includes this feature on the device during setup. `--enable_nat_feature` And if the NAT feature was not enabled (by this parameter or by default), the test is skipped. With this implementation, the test does not have time to turn on the NAT feature during startup, and the test is skipped, which does not allow working with sonic builds in which the NAT feature is not enabled by default.

Thanks, I will add this sistuation.

@[vmorokhx](https://github.com/vmorokhx) Hi, vmorokhx, there is a question. If we don't have 'nat' feature in show feature status, can --enable_nat_feature enable nat?

> @[vmorokhx](https://github.com/vmorokhx) Hi, vmorokhx, there is a question. If we don't have 'nat' feature in show feature status, can --enable_nat_feature enable nat?

Hi, if NAT feature is not displayed in `show feature status`, it means that NAT is not compiled in this SONiC image
https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/blob/master/rules/config#L145
Therefore, we cannot enable the NAT feature in this case, if I got it right.

> > @[vmorokhx](https://github.com/vmorokhx) Hi, vmorokhx, there is a question. If we don't have 'nat' feature in show feature status, can --enable_nat_feature enable nat?
> 
> Hi, if NAT feature is not displayed in `show feature status`, it means that NAT is not compiled in this SONiC image https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/blob/master/rules/config#L145 Therefore, we cannot enable the NAT feature in this case, if I got it right.

Got it, thanks.

@anish-n
In inner_hash_test.py was removed checker of balancing inside the LAG(old code lines 486-492). This checker is not correct, as we testing "SET_ECMP_HASH" in which balancing exists only between the PortChannels and not "inside" them. Previously it was always in "skip" because t0 has only 1 member in PortChannels.

latestReviews.body: Suggestion - instead of increasing timeout for all services, create two sets - one for services that complete before warmboot finishes (swss. syncd, teamd, bgp etc), and one for the other services (snmp, telemetry, acms, dhcp_relay, etc.
